awd_abstract_narration:
Living and Learning STEM (L2S) is an S-STEM program at Lycoming College designed to attract and support 14-16 low-income, academically talented undergraduate students pursuing degrees in astronomy/physics, biology, chemistry or mathematics. L2S Scholars will be recruited from the local rural region and from national and regional charter school networks that are already part of existing educational partnerships. In addition, Lycoming College will adapt and implement strategies and practices that will address the academic, financial, and social factors underlying student retention and academic success.  Key components of this enhanced support include a living-learning community (LLC) that will house two cohorts of L2S scholars along with other non-participating STEM students; a mentorship program that establishes relationships with faculty, upperclassmen, alumni, and an STEM career advisor; and an enhanced academic experience program that will provide at least one guaranteed paid summer internship and/or research experience for each L2S Scholar. Finally, these strategies and practices will be integrated into a holistic system that ultimately ensures graduation of a maximum number of individuals who will enter the STEM workforce or continue to pursue graduate studies in STEM-related fields.

The impact of supports aimed at social interactions and psychosocial learning factors have been under-researched in STEM education in favor of more cognitive and behavioral factors.  The L2S project will generate knowledge about whether a STEM-based LLC, mentorships, and enhanced academic experiences will improve retention and graduation rates among academically talented, low-income STEM majors by minimizing feelings of social isolation and improving like-minded community interactions throughout their undergraduate tenure. Through assessment and evaluation, the project will measure the overall effectiveness of the program by collecting assessments from L2S scholars and their non-participating cohort. The project will also seek to empirically identify the variables of the program that best correlate with: (1) improved factors of psychosocial learning; (2) attraction/recruitment; (3) retention; and (4) graduation, thus allowing us to recommend improvements to the program as needed.

por.por_cntn:
The goal of Lycoming College’s Living and Learning S-STEM program was to improve academic success, retention, and four-year graduation rates of STEM-interested, academically successful incoming students with high financial need. These S-STEM scholars resided in a living-learning community as first-year students, enrolled in a STEM-related first year seminar, and were given academic and cohort support throughout their four years at Lycoming College. All S-STEM scholars were individually mentored by faculty members, a STEM career counselor, a resident student mentor, and an alumni mentor working in their field of study. Funds granted by NSF were used to award $7,400 annual scholarships for two cohorts of students, designated S-STEM Scholars, for four years.  The first cohort (five students) entered in fall 2018 and the second in fall 2019 (nine students).

 

Each S-STEM scholar was given $3000 to apply towards a summer research or internship experience.  Through regular meetings with our STEM career advisor, S-STEM scholars were encouraged to seek out summer research and internship opportunities either off-campus through the NSF's Research Experience for Undergraduates (REU) program, through other programs, or on campus with Lycoming faculty. S-STEM scholars completed a total of 12 internships/research experiences through summer 2022. 

 

In terms of retention, academic performance, and student satisfaction, the S-STEM program was highly successful, especially given the fact that students of high financial need tend to have low overall academic success and retention in college. Of the original 14 students from the combined cohorts, two left the program as sophomores because they switched to non-science majors, for an overall retention rate of 86 %. These two scholarships were then awarded to two academically successful sophomore Lycoming STEM students with high financial need.  All 14 S-STEM scholars graduated within four years of matriculation. The average overall of our S-STEM Scholars was 3.67. Of the 14 STEM Scholars, five graduated Magna Cum Laude (3.9 – 4.0 GPA), one graduated Magna Cum Laude (3.70 - 3.89 GPA), and two graduated Cum Laude (3.50 - 3.69 GPA). Two S-STEM Scholars were given the Chieftain Award, the highest honor bestowed upon a Lycoming senior student.  

 

S-STEM Scholars have gone on to graduate school in STEM fields, to technical positions in industry, for further training in health professions, and into education. Based in part on the success of our S-STEM program, the College instituted a program known as the Frances Knights Skeath STEM Scholars Program that targets similar groups of incoming STEM-interested students. This new program ise using many of the support features we have implemented for our S-STEM students. Thus, our S-STEM grant has not only been an opportunity to produce a new cohort of scientists from financially needy backgrounds, but has also allowed us to gain experience in this type of effort and see it implemented in a sustained way at our institution, and hopefully, to provide a model for similar programs at other institutions.

 


Last Modified: 05/13/2024
Modified by: David R Broussard
